years.label: Year 7
years.overview: We kick off KS3 by learning how to create crisp, scalable graphics. Think “logo designer” energy.

topics.title: Developing vector graphics
topics.summary: Create digital artwork using shapes, paths and layers — with a focus on precision and design choices.
topics.intro: Vector graphics are made from shapes and paths, so they stay sharp at any size. Perfect for logos, icons, and anything that shouldn’t turn into pixel soup.
learningGoals: Use shapes and lines to build images
Organise work using layers and grouping
Choose colours, fonts and alignment with purpose
mastery: Create a logo/icon that meets a brief
Export correctly (size, file type, transparent background)

years.label: Year 8
years.overview: This is where we start programming properly: writing Python that takes input, makes decisions, repeats actions, and produces outputs you can actually use.

topics.title: Introduction to Python Programming
topics.summary: Learn the core building blocks: variables, selection, iteration, and tidy program structure.
topics.intro: Python is a general-purpose programming language. We’ll use it to learn how programs store data, make decisions, and repeat steps — like a robot with slightly better handwriting.
learningGoals: Use variables to store and update values
Take input and produce clear output
Debug common errors and explain fixes
mastery: Build small programs (quiz, calculator, simple game)

years.label: Year 9
years.overview: We focus on working with collections of data in Python — the real world is rarely one value at a time. (Sadly.)

topics.title: Python programming with sequences of data
topics.summary: Use strings and lists, loop through data, and build programs that manage collections reliably.
topics.intro: Sequences let you store and process multiple values: strings (characters) and lists (items). This is the step from “toy programs” to “useful programs”.
learningGoals: Create and use lists and strings
Access items by index (and avoid off-by-one chaos)
Use common sequence operations (len, in, slicing basics)
Write code that’s readable and testable
mastery: Write programs that store many values (scores, names, readings)
Loop through sequences to compute results (max, min, average, counts)
Explain what an algorithm does step-by-step
Test using different data to prove it works
